E9271796CDFA48FC8698C00F2F474323.description: identifying and selecting appropriate software programs for constructing text

DB105180806141EAA661400D0EBB3B86.description: Use a range of software including word processing programs to construct, edit and publish written text, and select, edit and place visual, print and audio elements

51755A062434450FBA9E7FA351B82869.description: using handwriting fluency with speed for a wide range of tasks

65E09629C88F49A19A5F685EEC0E85A6.description: Write using clearly-formed joined letters, and develop increased fluency and automaticity

E4CB9A2274B5412F883FFD4A70B30018.description: revising written texts: editing for grammatical and spelling accuracy and clarity of the text, to improve the connection between ideas and the overall flow of the piece

A4C8E745E4314F65911ED28B2DFA2FA6.description: Re-read and edit for meaning by adding, deleting or moving words or word groups to improve content and structure

02AC9321039E41ACA6767385D41F25CB.description: using grammatical features including different types of verb groups/phrases, noun groups/phrases, adverb groups/phrases and prepositional phrases for effective descriptions as related to purpose and context (for example, development of a character’s actions or a description in a report)

717FBF4FD13D4B2DA56D8C7E95EF0F91.description: using appropriate simple, compound and complex sentences to express and combine ideas

D31540CE79E449F081E60D9035A9CD58.description: using research from print and digital resources to gather ideas, integrating information from a range of sources; selecting text structure and planning how to group ideas into paragraphs to sequence content, and choosing vocabulary to suit topic and communication purpose

484CA67D237F4087AACF7289B061733B.description: Plan, draft and publish imaginative, informative and persuasive texts containing key information and supporting details for a widening range of audiences, demonstrating increasing control over text structures and language features

F0F44F432DFA43109FCEC21FB34A418F.description: bringing subject and technical vocabulary and concept knowledge to new reading tasks, selecting and using texts for their pertinence to the task and the accuracy of their information

A81133F09F1A43FE901B4A6116F5A0B0.description: inferring meaning from the ways communication occurs in digital environments including the interplay between words, images, and sounds

B99DF1DC075348D1B022E446980A7B71.description: finding the main idea of a text

0B7B75AA710C47D2945085187891307E.description: building and using prior knowledge and vocabulary

2F28BD5C64694CF2A781F339F0DA58CC.description: making connections between information in print and images

854D56313DFF46FC857B8EA7D91BEF21.description: making connections between the text and students’ own experience and other texts

7F4031E0E32C4375BF4AA81F11BE4F7C.description: Use comprehension strategies to build literal and inferred meaning to expand content knowledge, integrating and linking ideas and analysing  and evaluating texts

230A83CDBD7B4706AF52A8D519B269DB.description: reading a wide range of different types of texts for pleasure

EAEE491A8F434610923D018A6C897AD9.description: reading aloud with fluency and expression

A41602676F274CB6B86006D4669434ED.description: reading new and different kinds of texts with the use of  established word identification strategies, including knowledge of the topic and of text type together with self monitoring strategies; including rereading, self questioning and pausing, and including self correction strategies such confirming and cross-checking

EEF13CDAE8B04E17ADEB6EC943A13F53.description: Read different types of texts by combining contextual , semantic, grammatical  and phonic knowledge using text processing strategies for example monitoring meaning, cross checking and reviewing

616958FC15D54383BB8EFE667BF38E48.description: describing the language which authors use to create imaginary worlds; how textual features such as headings, subheadings, bold type and graphic organisers are used to order and present information, and how visual codes are used, for example those used in advertising to represent children and families so that viewers identify with them

0C320A0EB92444C4BE4D700A12632266.description: Identify characteristic features used in imaginative, informative and persuasive texts to meet the purpose of the text

E4C70283113F4335B67EF66B895F99C9.description: reporting on a topic in an organised manner, providing relevant facts and descriptive detail to enhance audience understanding, and beginning to refer to reliable sources to support claims

11ADCCDA22E147459CBC15EE8870AB80.description: Plan, rehearse and deliver presentations incorporating learned content and taking into account the particular purposes and audiences

DB77607491E246F3A0D3BF3F07D316FE.description: exploring the effects of changing voice tone, volume, pitch and pace in formal and informal contexts

6BE211293DCE4D4EA5179893F7AA7A30.description: choosing a variety of appropriate words and prepositional phrases, including descriptive words and some technical vocabulary, to communicate meaning accurately

9BC21723DAEB4EBBB823CF9292B53211.description: developing appropriate speaking and listening behaviours including acknowledging and extending others’ contributions, presenting ideas and opinions clearly and coherently

D51A2240507A4CB59313C2455202A095.description: participating in pair, group, class and school speaking and listening situations, including informal conversations, class discussions and presentations

B43D3F514B604B6E8CBDE57B5434F2D7.description: Use interaction skills such as acknowledging another’s point of view and linking students’ response to the topic, using familiar and new vocabulary and a range of vocal effects such as tone, pace, pitch and volume to speak clearly and coherently

BB0A7DC5E72642FAB66666119B7B0470.description: discussing levels of language — slang, colloquial (everyday) and formal language — and how their appropriateness changes with the situation and audience. Presenting ideas and opinions at levels of formality appropriate to the context and audience

9D91A5A05A6A4E47AC1E34A0A89590C9.description: making notes about a task, asking questions to clarify or follow up information, and seeking assistance if required

744A63336A264512891280CEF2A3A205.description: Interpret ideas and information in spoken texts and listen for key points in order to carry out tasks and use information to share and extend ideas and information

05352C5ACBBC4FE0B8B9CCC410C92326.description: viewing documentaries and news footage from different periods, comparing the style of presentation, including costumes and iconography with contemporary texts on similar topics and tracking changing views on issues, for example war, race, gender

9D5A2F5C647B4B6DB626BA2D1680EA1D.description: Identify and explain language features of texts from earlier times and compare with the vocabulary, images, layout and content of contemporary texts

5CFA31368A5E4FAF8F786FEB7E283A47.description: collaboratively plan, compose, sequence and prepare a literary text along a familiar storyline, using film, sound and images to convey setting, characters and points of drama in the plot

D422E817B600464589AB4BFA8D07316D.description: Create literary texts by developing storylines, characters and settings

C25857F87A6A4DD88DDEC1DD1BF74489.description: drawing upon literary texts students have encountered and experimenting with changing particular aspects, for example the time or place of the setting, adding characters or changing their personalities, or offering an alternative point of view on key ideas

78D9798C2549448C8287FDF0091BF6EC.description: Create literary texts that explore students’ own experiences and imagining

4910A5D41A32450CBBFA5CF6649033E8.description: discussing poetic language, including unusual adjectival use and how it engages us emotionally and brings to life the poet’s subject matter, for example ‘He grasps the crag with crooked hands’ (Alfred, Lord Tennyson); ‘Wee ... tim’rous beastie’ (Robert Burns)

F6A70321E968474C9D0E48E78DDD1421.description: defining spoonerisms, neologisms and puns and exploring how they are used by authors to create a sense of freshness, originality and playfulness

308EA7CB3D384032A5C0FE6F2CEF932D.description: Understand, interpret and experiment with a range of devices and deliberate word play in poetry and other literary texts, for example nonsense words, spoonerisms, neologisms and puns

3D4B8A5799D048808D6C1A58A1FE84C2.description: identifying pivotal points in the plot where characters are faced with choices and commenting on how the author makes us care about their decisions and consequences

0B5D2F1E8AB5495C9A2F6924EB785A3E.description: examining the author’s description of a character’s appearance, behaviour and speech and noting how the character’s development is evident through his or her dialogue and changing relationships and the reactions of other characters to him or her

128A3F3D8E334CF48F011A5DC9D1F6D8.description: Discuss how authors and illustrators make stories exciting, moving and absorbing and hold readers’ interest by using various techniques, for example character development and plot tension

75B934FFB09743C3A923A5A551B1F42F.description: sharing views using appropriate metalanguage (for example ‘The use of the adjectives in describing the character really helps to create images for the reader’)

D2CE1C7FAB8E4E47935601D44A88019D.description: examining the author’s description of a character’s appearance, behaviour and speech and noting how the character’s development is evident through his or her dialogue and changing relationships and the reactions of other characters to him or her

493E2ACC0737407C9C09794CD00128CF.description: Use metalanguage to describe the effects of ideas, text structures and language features of literary texts

79B09DF61EF54892A6D03D1049CF0540.description: drawing comparisons between multiple texts and students’ own experiences. Commenting orally, in written form and in digital reviews on aspects such as: 'Do I recognise this in my own world?'; 'How is this text similar to or different from other texts I’ve read?'; 'How common is it to human experience in the real world?'; 'What new ideas does it bring?'; ’How do they fit with what I believe?'

9A5F643595004C6DAD0F85407A53EA65.description: sharing and discussing students’ own and others’ understanding of the effects of particular literary techniques on their appreciation of texts

471C1B1C6A4C4262B99567064EC50253.description: Discuss literary experiences with others, sharing responses and expressing a point of view

6D1DE05BE01742E4BBD1AB524E9C3EBD.description: comparing different authors’ treatment of similar themes and text patterns, for example comparing fables and allegories from different cultures and quest novels by different authors

44E2FBAD4AA34EBD9D368CBC064F7977.description: commenting on how authors have established setting and period in different cultures and times and the relevance of characters, actions and beliefs to their own time

952D6DB2B0924DA7AD18588ACA46FFA0.description: Make connections between the ways different authors may represent similar storylines, ideas and relationships

5D2BB4794A194C219106708851BD57A1.description: using knowledge of sounds and visual patterns to read and write more complex letter combinations that have multiple representations in writing, for example ‘boy’ and ‘boil’, ‘howl’ and ‘foul’, ‘taught ’and ‘saw’

EB79F3DBC1C1430B9D6ED109DCF2EBE9.description: recognising unstressed vowels in multisyllabic words and how these vowel sounds are written, for example ‘builder’ and ‘animal’

10ED88DDE70C41D797FDBB70629D325B.description: using phonic generalisations to read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter combinations, for example ‘straightaway’ and ‘thoughtful’

9043301B0B4C4AB7880FC60D1FEA0DDC.description: Understand how to use phonic knowledge to read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter combinations, including a variety of vowel sounds and known prefixes and suffixes

E45C4929784A48D7A8D0B0FA90728FFE.description: using meaning and context to determine the spelling of homophones, for example ‘there’ and ‘their’; ‘no’ and ‘know’

A15DE406A9164AAFAAE22261CAF62C96.description: Read and write a large core of high frequency words including homophones and know how to use context to identify correct spelling

0BD5592FAADE47B481F9B13A03D5486E.description: using knowledge of common prefixes and suffixes to spell words and explore their meaning, for example ‘friendly’, ‘calmly’ and ‘cleverly’ and ‘misfortune’

2CAD8D3C40CB464A89C9FFCF73999B61.description: building morphemic word families and exploring word origins, for example ‘tricycle’, ‘triangle’ and ‘triple’

698C01453AF243B4BDC841228D1DF4EE.description: building morphemic word families and exploring word origins, for example the prefix ‘nat’ means source, birth or tribe in ‘nature’, ‘natural’ and ‘native’

AED73293AA4048DA8B421BB93F3FF4D5.description: applying generalisations for adding affixes, for example ‘hope’ and ‘hoping’, ‘begin’ and ‘beginning’, ‘country’ and ‘countries’

D4557A61A0F64DE4AB402B783071E321.description: Understand how to use knowledge of letter patterns including double letters, spelling generalisations, morphemic word families, common prefixes and suffixes and word origins to spell more complex words

DFD39E33340A47E280297912F7DADC3E.description: building etymological knowledge about word origins (for example 'thermometer') and building vocabulary from research about technical and subject specific topics

EF4AECF5FBE44738B19FD21A0C2D4449.description: Incorporate new vocabulary from a range of sources into students’ own texts including vocabulary encountered in research

BF8AC0B6D21A450ABC8EACE5CAF415C4.description: examining visual and multimodal texts, building a vocabulary to describe visual elements and techniques such as framing, composition and visual point of view and beginning to understand how these choices impact on viewer response

B28F9B21EEC740B7941F582CE7F2C949.description: Explore the effect of choices when framing an image, placement of elements in the image, and salience on composition of still and moving images in a range of types of texts

1B6ED6D5A8264118A3B66E3DE00F297D.description: investigating in texts how adverb group/phrases and prepositional phrases can provide details of the circumstances surrounding a happening or state (for example, ‘At midnight (time) he rose slowly (manner) from the chair (place) and went upstairs (place)’

D3FB5981691844A89925530876D91BB6.description: Understand how adverb groups/phrases and prepositional phrases work in different ways to provide circumstantial details about an activity

C56E723E753F4FC795B2AB3C598FE2E9.description: investigating examples of quoted (direct) speech (‘He said, “I’ll go to the park today”’) and reported (indirect) speech (‘He told me he was going to the park today’) and comparing similarities and differences

C0B565FEC7A5461A937A6E6E703D9F88.description: Investigate how quoted (direct) and reported (indirect) speech work in different types of text

C9E0C9415A71462D9319BD9C6671D7E1.description: creating richer, more specific descriptions through the use of noun groups/phrases (for example, in narrative texts, ‘their very old Siamese cat’; in reports, 'its extremely high mountain ranges')

AE20A7DE766D4AB08A9C3DD0871865B4.description: Understand that the meaning of sentences can be enriched through the use of noun groups/phrases and verb groups/phrases and prepositional phrases

A9676CBD56C443BB8E2D37A9952ADD00.description: participating in online searches for information using navigation tools and discussing similarities and differences between print and digital information

DAB15D4AEED64E87B9B8D2BA950E48A6.description: Identify features of online texts that enhance readability including text, navigation, links, graphics and layout

A28BAEF5E54845DEAF2DABE8C6B1350C.description: experimenting with the use of quotation marks in students’ own writing

770B122D33F94D94B07AF385CD7DF34C.description: exploring texts to identify the use of quotation marks

F619330721F147608102DC3A8256D815.description: Recognise how quotation marks are used in texts to signal dialogue, titles and quoted (direct) speech

357DEC6F5ECF432BA7FF7E21C9183FF8.description: describing how text connectives link sections of a text providing sequences through time, for example ‘firstly’, ‘then’, ‘next’, and ‘finally’

E5ADDC08C9DF466284C88C4E8EF6D973.description: identifying how participants are tracked through a text by, for example, using pronouns to refer back to noun groups/phrases

834B339E7D704E0E82E8DF6E246EB32F.description: knowing how authors construct texts that are cohesive and coherent through the use of: pronouns that link to something previously mentioned; determiners (for example ‘this’, ‘that’, ‘these’, ‘those’, ‘the’,); text connectives that create links between sentences (for example ‘however’, ‘therefore’, ‘nevertheless’, ‘in addition’, ‘by contrast’, ‘in summary’)

3BE6D88BE4D748C3A1D67A126507FC75.description: Understand how texts are made cohesive through the use of linking devices including pronoun reference and text connectives

D1040DC11DE8493F877FF2F13F4BDA3E.description: becoming familiar with the typical stages and language features of such text types as: simple narrative, procedure, simple persuasion texts and information reports

ECF5B48B3230478AB3D5BF5B364574A9.description: Understand how texts vary in complexity and technicality depending on the approach to the topic, the purpose and the intended audience

906E1F2266AE4F8B8E5A517D86214B21.description: identifying ways thinking verbs are used to express opinion, for example ‘I think’, ‘I believe’, and ways summary verbs are used to report findings, for example ‘we concluded’

5D712B00FC8E41BB895981A41A01E616.description: Understand differences between the language of opinion and feeling and the language of factual reporting or recording

F0D9FF9B2489482FB8A183F20DD0EF67.description: recognising the importance of using inclusive language

595436BC1B8044F2B0D61C7ACF6289D2.description: understanding how age, status, expertise and familiarity influence the ways in which we interact with people and how these codes and conventions vary across cultures

B4D016E327E14D5F98E6FB03391987C6.description: recognising that language is adjusted in different contexts, for example in degree of formality when moving between group discussions and presenting a group report

B6AB5833874646B6ABDF85AD81A87E79.description: recognising that we can use language differently with our friends and families, but that Standard Australian English is typically used in written school texts and more formal contexts

831D72C852F940CEA193FA1B9426E31A.description: Understand that social interactions influence the way people engage with ideas and respond to others for example when exploring and clarifying the ideas of others, summarising their own views and reporting them to a larger group

1B445C799F8F44958B0D315652377314.description: identifying commonly used words derived from other cultures

8807A763DC854A8C93DFE49F72A55C4F.description: identifying words used in Standard Australian English that are derived from other languages, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages, and determining if the original meaning is reflected in English usage, for example example ‘kangaroo’, ‘tsunami’,’ typhoon’, ‘amok’, ‘orang–utan’

48B0D3D49DA043C4891B1CF24E47A909.description: Understand that Standard Australian English is one of many social dialects used in Australia, and that while it originated in England it has been influenced by many other languages
